Some bright comb jellies to add more light to your holidays.   Wondering how comb jellies produce such a beautiful display? This #InternationalPolarBearDay we re celebrating one of the Arctic s most iconic animals!   Polar bears are perfectly suited for life on ice. They sport large padded claws and webbed toes which give them the ability to walk across the ice and swim as needed. They are specially evolved for the cold with black skin underneath their dense translucent fur coat that absorbs sunlight and keeps the bears warm! But being so well-adapted for the cold means they face a major threat: climate change. Warming temperatures cause more ice to melt earlier in the year making hunting increasingly difficult which causes bears to starve. The climate crisis is something we know how to combat and our oceans can be a key player in this battle. But immediate action is needed to tackle climate change to protect our future and our planets future. A juvenile humpback whale that has been entangled in fishing gear for months is finally free! The whale was first seen earlier this month with rope from fishing gear wrapped around its tail. Given the state of its health and injuries it s estimated that it may have been entangled for as long as six months. Fortunately a team from NOAA was able to find the whale and cut the rope freeing it from its entanglement. However even with the gear off scientists fear it may not survive the injuries it sustained. Entanglement in fishing gear is a top threat to endangered animals off the West Coast including humpback whales. Sadly 75% of reported whale entanglements are fatal as whales can drag heavy fishing gear for months hindering their ability to dive and feed and leading to starvation and infection. We hope this whale is one of the fortunate individuals to survive an entanglement. Whales deserve to have safe passage as they migrate and feed off our shores! Oceana campaigns for stronger protections for whales to reduce wildlife entanglements like this one and is pushing for  whale-safe  ropeless gear that is a viable way to keep fishermen on the water and is safer for whales and sea turtles.   : NOAA

Protecting Patagonias Hidden Gem   Katalalixar   a far-flung maze of islands and fjords to the west of the Patagonian ice fields   is the ancestral homeland of the Kaw sqar people. Beneath its glacier-chilled surface is an underwater wonderland teeming with life.   Now we face the challenge of protecting this part of Patagonia and safeguarding Katalalixar from industrial threats. To do so we funded a story-gathering project with Kaw sqar residents in the town of Puerto Eden to document and map out their traditional knowledge of the local land and sea. The work then inspired a  cultural  expedition which paired Oceana staff with a five-member Kaw sqar family on a 15-day journey. The journey was far from easy   storms food shortages and treacherous seas tested our resilience. But it was all worth it to work towards our goal of persuading the government to bolster protections for this ecologically and culturally important region by designating it as a national park.   The expeditions footage was turned into a documentary film that premiered in January 2023 in order to shine a spotlight on the issue and generate support to  protect the marine ecosystem. We are proud to support the Kaw sqar residing in Puerto Eden in protecting their local land and sea! See more of the documentary with the #linkinbio.

THEN AND NOW: Back in 2017 little was known of Chile s Pisagua Bay seabed until Oceana and the uarturoprat decided to investigate. On our first expedition we were amazed by what we found. This vibrant area is home to coral banks manta rays Chilean jack mackerel and so much more. We knew right away: this place had to be protected   so we took action! Fast forward to 2023 our vision is finally a reality! Following three more expeditions and a scientific recommendation of protection Chile has officially established the Pisagua Sea Marine Protected Area (MPA). Spanning over 181500 acres this MPA safeguards not just marine habitats and species but also the livelihoods of local artisanal fishers who depend on these waters. Oceana worked closely with Pisagua s artisanal fishers to ensure the MPA s creation supports the ocean and their economy.  Pisagua Sea  is now the first MPA in Chile designed to both protect marine life and the people who rely on it. Not all hermit crabs use shells as their home! Most species rely on borrowed shells to protect their soft abdomens but deepwater hermit crabs (family Parapaguridae) take a unique approach.   These crabs team up with sea anemones (family Hormathiidae) in an incredible partnership. Initially the crab inhabits a shell but over time the anemone overgrows and dissolves the shell forming a flexible covering that grows with the crab! This mutualistic relationship benefits both: the crab gets protection from predators like octopuses thanks to the anemones stinging tentacles while the anemone enjoys a free ride across the seafloor.  : Image courtesy of the NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research 2015 Hohonu Moana.

A new study has found that some large fishes use sharks to remove parasites. Research revealed that large open-ocean fish like tuna sometimes scrape against sharks to get rid of parasites and seem to prefer scraping against them even than other fish of the same species.These findings reveal new ways that species can be connected beneath the waves   which is both fascinating and highlights threats to ocean wildlife. Global shark populations are declining which the authors suggest may eventually lead to these fish having a harder time ridding themselves of parasites and threatening their overall health. Our oceans are an interconnected web of biodiversity. When one species declines many others can suffer as well. We must safeguard vulnerable marine species and promote biodiversity so that all ocean wildlife can thrive.

Watching a school of fish swim in perfect harmony is mesmerizing but have you ever wondered why they move so seamlessly together? 1  To avoid predators. Swimming in sync makes it harder for predators to focus on a single fish reducing the chances of an attack. By sticking together they create a confusing ever-shifting mass that keeps them safer. 2  To save energy.Much like migrating birds fish move in unison to travel more efficiently. When swimming together the hydrodynamics of the fish school can allow them to swim using less energy than if they were swimming on their own. 3  To feed.More eyes mean a better chance of spotting food! Why Lobster is Off the Menu in Brazil   If you found yourself on the beaches of Cear  Brazil you might be tempted to try one of the main delicacies of the Brazilian Northeast: lobster. But right now that s not an option. From November 1st to April 30th lobster fishing is strictly off-limits a crucial pause that allows populations to recover after years of overfishing. And as of February 1st even selling lobster in Brazil is illegal. Why? Because beneath the waves something crucial is happening: lobsters are reproducing.   Without this seasonal break the future of lobster (and the thousands of families who rely on it for their livelihood) would be in jeopardy. Oceana s 2019 stock assessment of red lobsters highlighted the urgency of this issue mobilizing artisanal fishers industry leaders and allies to support catch limits. Lobster is more than just a delicacy it s a lifeline for over 15000 families in Brazil.  The closed season is one of the main tools for ensuring the sustainability of the species  says artisanal fisherman Tobias Soares.  When we respect these rules we are defending the lobster and our livelihood.   : Oceana/Christian BragaOceanaBrasil

From the brink of extinction: The brown pelican s comeback Once nearly wiped out by the feather trade then poisoned by pesticides the brown pelican is the original success story of the Endangered Species Act (ESA). In the late 1800s these iconic coastal birds were hunted relentlessly for their feathers prized in high fashion. Then in the 1950s they faced a new threat: DDT. This toxic pesticide made its way up the food chain causing pelican eggshells to thin and break before chicks could hatch. Their numbers plummeted. Listed as endangered in 1970 under the Endangered Species Act the brown pelican s turning point came when DDT was banned in the United States in 1972 and with habitat protection thanks to the ESA. As DDT contamination levels dropped their populations rebounded. By 2009 they were fully removed from the Endangered Species List. Today brown pelicans soar along North America s coasts a powerful reminder that the Endangered Species Act works. But now following proposed cuts to NOAA s ability to defend threatened wildlife this critical law is also under attack.   Join us in defending the Endangered Species Act because every species deserves the same chance at survival that the brown pelican had! Link in bio.

Victory for Brazil with new lobsters catch limits implemented!   Since the 1950 s red spiny lobster and green lobster populations in Brazil have been in steep decline. The potential collapse of this fishery would not only impact these marine species and our oceans but also local artisanal fishers who depend on this activity for their food and livelihood.  For years fishers scientific community industry stakeholders and nonprofit organizations like Oceanabrasil have been working together to try and address this issue. Now through scientific studies stock assessments and coordination with fisherfolk we have helped convince the government to finally act towards a sustainable lobster fishery!  Tobias da Silva a local lobster fisherman emphasizes the importance of adhering to the newly established regulations: Now what needs to be done is to respect the rules. It needs to start with us fisherfolks this respect. And the government needs to do its part. If everyone does their part we ensure that the lobster species do not come to an end.

The recovery of northern cod is under threat by a recent decision from Canadas Fisheries Minister. After a 32-year moratorium the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has announced the reopening of the commercial northern cod fishery along with increasing the Canadian fishing quota by 38.5%.The decision made as the stock barely moved out of the critical zone poses significant risks to the future recovery of this iconic fish population and a centuries-old fishery that is vital for Newfoundland and Labrador ocean ecosystems and coastal communities. It ignores scientific advice and the urgent need to address the impacts of decades of overfishing and short-sighted fisheries management. We are deeply concerned with this short-sighted decision as opening the commercial fishery puts the stock at significant risk and undermines efforts to rebuild healthy oceans and coastal communities. Read oceana_canada s full press release with the #linkinbio.

When a plastic bottle enters the ocean it doesn t stay a bottle forever! Instead plastics break up into smaller and smaller pieces in the ocean. These microplastics can be swallowed by tiny marine animals and when larger animals eat those animals they re unknowingly eating plastic too. Ocean wildlife that eat too many microplastics could suffer from internal injuries delayed growth and even serious behavior changes that threaten the animal s health and long-term survival. Saving fish strengthening futures!   In the eastern Philippines lies the island municipality of Daram. With the longest coastline in its province of Samar the island is making waves in the fight against post-harvest fish loss a major challenge for food security and the livelihoods of small-scale fishers.   At a recent Stakeholders  Forum & Field Visit Vice Mayor Lucia Astorga spoke to emphasize the importance of reducing fish loss to ensure more food better nutrition and stronger incomes for coastal communities. Big changes are happening! Daram is implementing a game-changing fish loss reduction plan and catch monitoring system across 58 barangays the smallest local government unit in the Philippines. These innovations which are supported by small-scale fishers government agencies and universities prioritize real solutions for a more sustainable ocean & future.   Oceana s Vice President Atty. Gloria Estenzo Ramos was able to visit and show her support for Daram s inspiring leadership and progress firsthand  because every fish saved means more food more income and a healthier ocean!   #SustainableFishing #FoodSecurity #SaveOurSeas #FishersFirst Oceana_ph

BREAKING: An oil tanker has collided with a cargo ship off the coast of Britain. Our thoughts are with everyone affected by this tragic event including the crew and first responders. This tragic event has raised serious environmental concerns. While it s too early to fully assess the impact to our oceans one vessel was reported to be carrying of jet fuel. Oceana_UK s Hugotagholm issued the following statement: This incident is a shocking reminder of the ferocious polluting power of oil. We are seeing burning slicks the threat of heavy fuel oil and toxic chemicals leaking in or near not one but two marine protected areas. Places that should be safe havens for wildlife. Southern North Sea and Holderness MPAs protect declining harbour porpoises and rich seafloor habitats both highly sensitive to these toxic spills. Oil is always an accident waiting to happen in our ocean and we are all familiar with its devastating impacts   seabirds slick with oil marine life struggling in tarry tidelines and a toxic legacy that can impact wildlife and coastal communities for years. More oil will always result in more spills.  Oceana staff members are on the ground monitoring the impacts of this toxic oil spill. We will share news about this event as it becomes available.

In 2021 Chile passed a law law regulating the distribution of single-use and disposable plastics in food establishments which came into play progressively. A central piece of this regulation was set to take effect on August 13 2024 and included among others the prohibition of distribution of any type of disposables for consumption within food establishments including food courts. However earlier in August Congress and the Government agreed to postpone the law by 18 months. However there still are already obligations in effect in Chile!For over a year food vendors have been prohibited from providing Styrofoam plastic cutlery straws or stirrers. Additionally supermarkets and convenience stores must accept and offer returnable bottles!Learn more at the #linkinbio.

Global sea ice just hit a record low. The amount of ice lost is enough to cover the United States east of the Mississippi River. But this isn t just about numbers sea ice is critical for keeping our planet cool and providing a home for polar bears seals and penguins.    With rising global temperatures the impacts are only getting worse. But there s still time to act. Reducing fossil fuel use and embracing clean energy can help slow ice loss and protect the species that depend on it.
